sen.j: 沙沙貴神社（ささきじんじゃ）は滋賀県蒲生郡安土町にある神社である。
sen.e: Sasaki-jinja Shrine stands at Azuchi-cho, Gamo-gun, Shiga Prefecture.
Sasaki-jinja Shrine stands at Azuchi-cho, Gamo County, Shiga Prefecture.
Sasaki-jinja Shrine stands at Azuchi-cho, Gamo County, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は県社。
sen.e: It is Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) and its old classification of shrines has been prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka).
It is Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) and its old classification of shrine has been prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka).
sen.cmt: its old classification of shrines > its old classification of shrine
sen.e: It is Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) and its old classification of shrine has been prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka).

sen.j: 少彦名命を主祭神として計四座五柱の神々を祀り、「佐佐木大明神」と総称する。
sen.e: It enshrines Sukunahikona no Mikoto as shusaijin (main enshrined deities) as well as five gods and four places in total, and is collectively called "Sasaki Daimyojin God".
It enshrines Sukunahikona no Mikoto as shusaijin (main enshrined deities) as well as five gods and four places in total, and is collectively called 'Sasaki Daimyojin God'.
It enshrines Sukunahikona no Mikoto as shusaijin (main enshrined deities) as well as five gods and four places in total, and is collectively called 'Sasaki Daimyojin God'.

sen.j: 佐佐木源氏の氏神であり、佐々木姓発祥地に鎮座する。
sen.e: It is the ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) for Sasaki-Genji (Minamoto clan), sitting in the place where the Sasaki family derived.
It is the ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) for Sasaki-Genji (Minamoto clan), sitting in the place where the Sasaki family derived.
It is the ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) for Sasaki-Genji (Minamoto clan), sitting in the place where the Sasaki family derived.

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 神代に少彦名神を祀ったことに始まり、古代に沙沙貴山君が大彦命を祭り、景行天皇が志賀高穴穂宮遷都に際して大規模な社殿を造営させたと伝わる。
sen.e: Legend says it had originally enshrined Sukunabikona no kami in a mythological age, Sasakiyamagimi worshiped Obiko no Mikoto in the ancient times, and then Emperor Keiko constructed a large scale of a sanctuary at the transfer of the capital to Shigatakaanahomiya.

Legend says it had originally enshrined Sukunabikona no kami in the mythological age, Sasakiyamagimi worshiped Obiko no Mikoto in the ancient times, and then Emperor Keiko constructed a large scale of a sanctuary at the transfer of the capital to Shigatakaanahomiya.

Legend says it had originally enshrined Sukunabikona no kami in the mythological age, Sasakiyamagimi worshiped Obiko no Mikoto in the ancient times, and then Emperor Keiko constructed a large scale of a sanctuary at the transfer of the capital to Shigatakaanahomiya.

sen.j: 後にこの地に土着した宇多源氏によって宇多天皇とその皇子であり宇多源氏の祖である敦實親王が祭られ それ以降佐々木源氏の氏神とされ、子々孫々が篤く崇敬していた。
sen.e: Later, the Emperor Uda as well as the Imperial Prince Atsumi who was the son of Emperor Uda and the founder of Uda-Genji (Minamoto clan) were worshipped by Uda-Genji, and subsequently they were venerated by their descendants as ujigami for Sasaki-Genji.

Later, Emperor Uda as well as the Imperial Prince Atsumi, who was the son of Emperor Uda, and the founder of Uda-Genji (Minamoto clan) were worshipped by Uda-Genji, and subsequently they were venerated by their descendants as ujigami for Sasaki-Genji.
sen.cmt: Wordの校正機能でエラーが出る為、カンマを入れました。the Imperial Prince Atsumi, who was the son of Emperor Uda, the Emperor Uda > Emperor Uda
sen.e: Later, Emperor Uda as well as the Imperial Prince Atsumi, who was the son of Emperor Uda, and the founder of Uda-Genji (Minamoto clan) were worshipped by Uda-Genji, and subsequently they were venerated by their descendants as ujigami for Sasaki-Genji.

sen.j: 婆沙羅大名の佐々木道誉や江戸時代天保年間に消失した社殿を再建した丸亀藩主京極高明、日露戦争203高地の戦いで有名な乃木希典もその一人である。
sen.e: The descendants included Doyo SASAKI who was Basara daimyo, Takaaki KYOGOKU who was the lord of Marugame and revived the domain main building of a Shinto shrine disappeared at Tenpo era of Edo period, and Maresuke NOGI who was famous for the battle for 203 kouchi in the Russo-Japanese War.

The descendants included Doyo SASAKI who was Basara daimyo, Takaaki KYOGOKU who was the lord of Marugame Domain and revived the main building of a Shinto shrine disappeared at Tenpo era of the Edo period, and Maresuke NOGI who was famous for the battle for 203 kouchi in the Russo-Japanese War.
sen.cmt: the lord of Marugame > the lord of Marugame Domain the domain main building > the main building Edo period > the Edo period
sen.e: The descendants included Doyo SASAKI who was Basara daimyo, Takaaki KYOGOKU who was the lord of Marugame Domain and revived the main building of a Shinto shrine disappeared at Tenpo era of the Edo period, and Maresuke NOGI who was famous for the battle for 203 kouchi in the Russo-Japanese War.

sen.j: 現在も宇多源氏・佐佐木源氏（佐々木氏、六角氏、京極氏、朽木氏、黒田氏、馬渕氏、堀部氏、青池氏、曲直瀬氏、森川氏、三井家など二百二十余姓）末裔の篤い信仰を集める。
sen.e: It has been still devoutly worshipped by the descendants of Uda-Genji as well as Sasaki-Genji (including about 220 clans such as, Sasaki clan, the Rokkaku clan, the Kyogoku clan, the Kutsuki clan, the Kuroda clan, the Mabuchi clan, the Horibe clan, the Aoike clan, the Manase clan, the Morikawa clan,Mitsui family).

It has been still devoutly worshipped by the descendants of Uda-Genji as well as Sasaki-Genji (including about 220 clans such as, the Sasaki clan, the Rokkaku clan, the Kyogoku clan, the Kutsuki clan, the Kuroda clan, the Mabuchi clan, the Horibe clan, the Aoike clan, the Manase clan, the Morikawa clan, the Mitsui family).

sen.j: 本殿、透塀、中門、権殿、拝殿、楼門、東廻廊、西廻廊の8棟は平安・鎌倉時代の様式で江戸時代に建立。
sen.e: The eight buildings, that is Honden, sukibei (transparent fence), chumon (inner gate), Gonden (associate shrine), haiden (a hall of worship), romon (two-storied gate), the east kairo (cloister), the west kairo were built in the Heian and Kamakura period style in the Edo period.

The eight buildings, that is honden, sukibei (transparent fence), chumon (inner gate), gonden (associate shrine), haiden (a hall of worship), romon (two-storied gate), the east kairo (cloister), the west kairo were built in the Heian and Kamakura period style in the Edo period.

The eight buildings, that is honden, sukibei (transparent fence), chumon (inner gate), gonden (associate shrine), haiden (a hall of worship), romon (two-storied gate), the east kairo (cloister), the west kairo were built in the Heian and Kamakura period style in the Edo period.
